prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To estimate the amount of CO we expect in our targets we use the relation between the 100 micron flux and the CO emission for IR bright galaxies from Solomon and Downes (1997). We compute the restframe 100 micron fluxes by first measuring the spectral index between our PACS 70, 100 and 160 micron data. We then assume that the CO profile will have a width between 200 and 250 km/secbased on similar CO observations of PG QSOs from Evans et al. 2006 and Scoville et al. 2003). As we are interested in the FWHM widths only for this initial study we seek a SNR of 3-5 at the FWHM.

The 12CO (1-0) line for our objects can be measured in the 3mm band. As such we placed one spectral window centered on the CO line. Assuming a width of 250km/sec, a velocity resolution of 40kmsec will give us sufficient sampling to estimate CO (1-0) line widths and hence the circular velocity. We can achieve this resolution observing he 2GHz bandwidth with a channel width of 7.813 MHz corresponding to 21-23 km/sec.

Previous interferometric CO observations of PG QSOs (e.g. Scoville et al. 2003, Evans et al. 2006) find that the gas is concentrated in a compact region, unresolved on 4" scales. We seek to botains 0.6" resolution to resolve the CO emission or place stringent limits on the CO surface density . Such estimates are required to constrain both the gas surface density and the star-formation efficiency but also to search for associations between the molecular gas and optical structure in the host galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal 4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum at 1.3 mm for all targets

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the expected 1mm fluxes from observations with Herschel at 160 microns. From our typical SED fits, we assume a conservative ratio of 30 between the measured flux at 160 microns and the flux at 1mm. Our targets have 160 $\mu$m fluxes above 270mJy. From this we inferr that their 1mm fluxes ar on the order of 9mJy. If we assume that the emission is uniformly distrubted in the 5.6" Herschel 70 micron PSF, the expected 1mm fluxes in a 1" beam are on the order of 200 microJy.

The 12CO (1-0) line for our objects can be measured in the 3mm band. As such we placed one spectral window centered on the CO line. Assuming a width of 250km/sec, a velocity resolution of 40kmsec will give us sufficient sampling to estimate CO (1-0) line widths and hence the circular velocity. We can achieve this resolution observing he 2GHz bandwidth with a channel width of 7.813 MHz corresponding to 21-23 km/sec.

Previous interferometric CO observations of PG QSOs (e.g. Scoville et al. 2003, Evans et al. 2006) find that the gas is concentrated in a compact region, unresolved on 4" scales. We seek to botains 0.6" resolution to resolve the CO emission or place stringent limits on the CO surface density . Such estimates are required to constrain both the gas surface density and the star-formation efficiency but also to search for associations between the molecular gas and optical structure in the host galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal 14
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The five brightest 160 micron type-2s are at redshifts less than 0.12 and we propose to observe their 12 CO (1-0) transition in ALMA's band3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The coevolution of central black holes (BH) and their host galaxies through starbursts and AGN feedback are major elements of recent galaxy evolution models. Here we propose to investigate these processes in a sample of 10 nearby, optically luminous AGN broad and narrow-line QSOs, by examining how their gas and dust properties change as a function of their type, luminosity, and total dust masses estimated from Herschel Observations. We request observations of the 12 CO(1-0) transition on kpc scales, to measure the cold gas surface densities as well as the dynamic mass and gravitational potential of the host galaxy and 1 mm continuum observations to map the coldest dust component and distinguish between dust associated with the nucleus and that residing in the host galaxy. Some models predict an evolutionary link between narrow and broad-line QSOs which would lead to different ISM properties. The proposed data will constrain those models and will constitute a fundamental dataset for studies of molecular gas and dust in local QSOs by almost doubling the number of interferometric studies, of combined cold dust and molecular gas, at higher resolution and sensitivity.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Hawaii at Hilo, University of
